Louie, on the raft, and Mac, still in the water, negotiat Phil onto the raft. Phil himself cannot help much. Mac clambers in as Louie finds the gash in Phil’s scalp. Some of the debris starting to sink.  96 97 49 WIDE ANGLE - The tiny rafts carrying three men surrounded by the debris of the crash, alone in the vast ocean.

Louie has a raft pocket open and is taking an inventory o the supplies: Hershey chocolate bars, half pint tins oF water, a brass mirror, a flare gun, sea dye, fish hooks, fishing line, air pumps, raft patch kits. Glassman didn’t make it. peat) Cup didn’t make it--

We’re not dying. Shut up. Louie carefully divides the six chocolate bars into small segments. He reads the instructions on the packet.
One square in the morning. One square at night. He gives a tin of water to Mac.
Two or three sips a day. A murmur from Phil. Louie looks at him.
Louie. ..
Yeah Phil.
I'm glad it’s you.
I’m glad it’s me too.  99 51
The three men lying in the raft. The raft peacefully bobs. Louie still holds the compress Phil’s head. Phil’s eyes are shut: sleeping. A thunk. Louie tenses. Mac is panicky:

What was that? A quiet beat as both men wait, listening. Another thunk, and the raft jostles. Hands on gunwhales, Louie looks carefully over the edge. Dark water. Hard to see. But a dark shape retreats just under the surface of the water. Louie’s eyes track it away until it is lost. His look hol out. Then his look tracks something back in: The dark shape, returning. As it disappears under the boat, it bumps its underside again.  100 52 We fade as he closes his eyes. Under the fade, one last fading-away thunk. ..
A high-pitched whining sound.
Eyes popping open. It is a bald day. The whining noise is distinguishable as engine noise. Louie bolts to a sitting position, looking up. Blue sky. Far above, a moving dot. A plane.
Hey! He scrambles to his feet.
- . . Hey! He waves:

- . . Hey! Hey! Struck by his own stupidity, he abandons arm-waving and scrambles to open the provision pocket on the raft. He to Mac the dye and he spills it into the water below. Phil still sleeps. Louie comes out with the flare gun. He fires up at the dot in the sky. Phil awakens to the so Louie, a holding look, gun at his side, staring up. The plane’s gnat-noise drones on, its course unchanged.

- . . Damnit! Down here! Another pop of the flare gun. Both Mac and Louie waving. But the drone is perceptibly less loud now; the plane is going away. Louie throws the gun down.  53 Mac turns away, looking out to sea. Louie comes up short, looking: Where he has just flung the flare gun, at his feet-- litt wrappers. He hunches and picks up a torn piece of paper. Printing i on its slick outside. Louie stares at the chocolate wrapper. He looks up. Mac, his back to us, motionless, resolutely looking out. Louie. He squats and does a panicky paw through the provision pocket. More wrappers. No chocolate. Straighten again.
+ + «Mac. Mac! His back. No reaction. Louie takes a step forward.
What did you do? Mac can’t reply. He looks away, out to sea. On his back we hear:
It doesn’t matter. Louie is too shocked to be angry. His tone is almost childlike:

Doesn’t matter? Mac looks so pathetic and helpless. Louie wants to hit hi but looks to Phil and decides not to make it worse. Instead, he checks the tins of water. Untouched. Louie si back down. Now what?  101 102 103 104 54 They sit in silence.

Bright day. The three men wear their shirts like hooded capes, protec themselves as best they can from the sun. Reality has set in. They will most likely die here. Mac breaks down crying. No one moves or says a word.

Later- DAY #9 104 We find the men a week later- Phil: dozing, protected as much as he can be by his shirt but he is red-skinnned, lip-chapped. Mac_is much worse off from the exposure, skin blistered, swollen, face peeling. Suddenly a look from Mac, reacting to: Louie. The little mirror is set next to him, pointing up the sky. The circle of the mirror is a glaring hot spot. Louie’s POV - the bright sun washing out the image of the albatross flying above. An albatross is just settling-- sitting on the lip of the raft to investigate the bobbing, glaring glass. Louie, just next to the bird, is frozen, tense. The bird’s black eyes peering. Wings folding. Claws gripp Louie’s hand flashes to the bird, grabbing its leg.

Okay!  105 55 Wild activity: flapping, writhing, pecking: Phil closes o it. He and Louie are a confusion of activity around the bird. Louie snaps its neck. The large bird is limp. phe men carefully set it down, cautiously withdrawing the ands.

Okay. Louie grabs the pliers. Mac and Phil watch as Louie rips the bird open. The men react to a stench from the opened bird. They hesitate over the specimen. PHIL (CONT’D I don’t know if I can do it. Another beat. Louie reaches in.
We gotta try. Louie passes some to Mac who hesitates, still feeling the guilt of the chocolate.
The men dry-heaving. They ease back into place, eyes watering. Taking sips of water sparingly.
We had to try. Panting beat. Then Phil has an idea:  106 107 56
Know what? He leans forward, to the provision pocket, and pulls out line.
.- +. Maybe the fish won’t be as picky.
The raft drifts in the vast ocean. Too far away to make o detail, but we hear a sudden cry -
Got it!

A pilot fish dangles on the end of Louie’s line-- ten inc of live food. Louie gets the hook out, kills the fish, ta a bite. Then he passes it alon to the others. They don't like it, but they need it, © they eat.
This is how the Japs eat fish. Raw.
If you ask me, it’s not food til you cook it. A little garlic. A ittle oil and lemon. When we get home, you come ‘round to my house. Mama’ll cook for you.
Remember the Eddie Rickenbacker story in Life magazine? Him and his crew ran out of fuel over the Pacific. They were drifting in rafts for twenty-four days.
And they made it, right?
They made it. But most of them lost their minds.  108 57
We gotta keep our minds sharp. Gotta keep talking... Mac_looks distressed. He looks out into the water. Louie realizes he needs to distract him. He needs to keep talki

You_know what you’re really going to love? Mama’s gnocchi. Nobod' makes gnocchi like her. So Tight, like clouds. She uses lots of eggs, Maybe twelve. The others listen, absorbed by the image he conjures up. MOVE AWAY from the raft as he speaks, his voice growing fainter as the raft grows smaller.
First, she makes the dough out_of very fine flour. So fine it’s like talcum powder. Then she beats up the egg yolks, and she drizzles them over the flour.

They heat of the sun pounds down on the men. The tins of water are all empty. The condition of the three men has drastically changed af weeks at sea. Their upper lips are burnt, cracked, ballooning so dramatically that they almost obscure their nostrils. The bodies are slashed with open cracks, after exposure to th elements. The men are emaciated. Mac’s breathing is louder, raspier  58-59 Louie pulls out the picture of his family. It fills him w deep sadness. He has to put it away before he cries.  60
Louie, Mac and Phil are gazing up at the stars.
You_believe God made the stars, Phil?
Yes, I do.
You think there’s some kind of a grand plan? Like why’d we live and others didn’t? Why are we here now? Phil considers.

Here’s the plan. (beat ) You go on doing the best you can. You ry to have some fun along the way Then one day it’s over. You e up and there’s an angel sitting at the edge of your bed, the angel says, you can ask me all those dumb questions now, because I’ve got the answers.
That’s what you believe?
That’s what I believe. Moments pass in silence. Mac stares out into the darkness.  112 113 61
30 foot swells. The men are now all in one raft, white knuckling it to hold on and not get tossed. The second ra is tied further from them in the distance. Phil closes his eyes in silent prayer.
(to the heavens) If you answer my prayers. +-you_ get me through this...I swear. --I'll do whatever you want. I'll dedicate my life to you. Please... Waves of water splash across his face.

The storm rages into the night. The men hold on tight as rafts are swept up and down on the huge swells. EXT. RAFT -— PACIFIC OCEAN DAY #22 113 Drops of water wake Louie. As if an answer to his prayer, the heavens open and rain pours down. The men throw back their heads, spread their arms, and open their mouths. The rain falls on them. It soothes their skin, washes the salt and sweat from their pores, and slides down their throats. A sensory explosion  114 62 They pull out the empty tins to collect water. Burning sun. DOWN to find the rafts, the men deteriorated further. Full beards, skeletal faces. Louie is removing Phil’s bandage.
How is it?
It stinks. But that’s the bandage, not you. He throws the bandage over the side.
We beat Rickenbacker’s record. Four days ago.

You keeping count? They hear a small noise in the water and realize a shark been drawn to the bloody bandage. Then, in the distance, they hear a distant plane engine. up to the sky. THEIR POV: A moving spot in the sky.  64 Mac comes to life, seeing the plane. Louie loads and fires a flare. Phil finds the mirror and it to reflect the sun towards the plane. Louie shoots off another flare. The look of all three men travels straight overhead with plane, which makes no acknowledgment. The plane passes, far off, and fades away. A couple of dark shapes are rippling up. Sharks. All three men are looking down at the shapes in the water when we hear a change in the engine noise. The men’s eyes rise back to the plane. It is no longer receding: it is starting to turn... banking. . . returning. . . dropping in altitude. Louie resumes waving. As the plane approaches it drops, lower, lower. The men wave. Just as we see the Red Circle, its guns start firing. Water kicks up in a line from each gun, walking toward th raft. The shark-shapes wriggle, reacting. The men bail out into the stained water.

Fizzing bullet-trails cut between the three men fighting stay submerged. Dark shapes are approaching the men in the water.

The plane flies on past. The sharks are back, almost on the thrashing bodies of th men. Desperately they haul themselves back into the raft. Louie is the first to flop back onto the raft; he helps P and Mac in; all panting. They hear the plane again. It’s coming back.
Get out!
I can't. He’s just too weak to move. Louie slides back into the wa Bullets shower the ocean around the raft.

Louie struggles to stay under the rafts. We can see the depression of Phil and Mac’s bodies. Neither one moves. Bullet holes pop through the canvas, shooting beams of li through the raft’s shadow. Bullets pierce the water throughout the following sequence: A shark approaching Louie is shot by a stream of bullets above. Louie sees a long cord straying off the end of the raft. grabs it.  123 124 66
Louie breaching, hooking his arms over the raft. He climb back in just as the shark comes back for another attack.
Phil! Mac! Beat. Phil speaks without moving or opening his eyes -

If the Japs are this bad, we might even win this damn war. Mac moves. Looks round. Sees the plane has gone. Then they hear the air hissing out of the raft. Water is filling up the bottom. One raft left, the other is shot t shit and already completely deflated. Louie hunts out the patch kits. The others search out the holes. Every time they move another hole is uncovered, hissing out air. And all the time the sharks are circling Phil grabs an air pump, screws it to a valve, and starts pumping. Bubbles push out of bullet holes, Louie works on @Pp ying patches, using the edge of the mirror to rough u the rubber round the hole before applying glue and patch. Phil keeps pumping hard. Suddenly a shark lunges up out of the water, mouth open, right at Louie - An oar sweeps past Louie’s head, striking the shark back the water. It’s Mac, come back to life. He beats the sharks with fur and power we’ve not seen in him before. Mac goes on swinging his oar, whacking at the sharks. Mac continues hitting the sharks away as Phil pushes the against his chest, inflating the raft.
The exhausted men continue with what little energy they h left. Mac stands ready with his oar. We can see this figh has taken a lot out of him.  125 126 67
Did you see that Mac surprise attack? Damn sharks were scared shit. He came down on that thing like a Goddamn dive bomber.

Saved your skinny ass. We see this means a great deal to Mac, though he hides it from the other men. Louie takes over the pumping. Later- 125 The sun goes down over the endless ocean. The men continu work into the night.

Louie is near the canvas bowl, stretched out. Mac lies with his head on Phil’s lap, not moving. The thr are barely alive, their flesh almost transparent, their b visible. They speak slowly, not much energy left. Quizzin each other to keep alive.
1937. Baseball. MVP.
Uh.., the kid from Detroit... Gerhinger.
Mac. Get in the game. He’s trying to make out what’s happening with Mac.
Mac?  68 No response from Mac: head-down, shoulders rhythmically moving with his rasping breath. Louie moves over to Mac.
Mac?
Still here. What you gonna make for breakfast, Zamp?
Your call.
Your mother’s gnocchi.
Gnocchi for breakfast? Okay. Why not?
Am I gonna die? After a moment-—
Maybe.
You think, tonight?
Maybe.
Yes, sir. I think tonight. Louie and Phil shuffle their weakened bodies until they’r lying on either side of Mac, their arms round him.
So you get your dough, and you roll it out... His voice fades into silence.
Quiet at the cut.  128

130 69 Gentle slap of water on the boat. Mac's body has been laid out face up, in a comfortable position. Louie is squatted at the back of the boat, waiting. Phil is praying as he finishes preparing Mac’s body.

Both men have hands on the corpse. They shove him off. The boat bobs, regaining balance. The men seat themselves, grabbing sides of the boat, steadying it, steadying themselves. The body bobs in the water. The men, looking at it. The body is abruptly grabbed, somehow, and briefly towed. It disappears into the water.
Louie looks at Phil. How frail and emaciated he is. He th looks up into the heavens. Into the clouds. Beautiful clo It’s almost as if he can hear music. The sounds of angels coming from the heavens.

Wide on the raft. Close on Louie. Face-up, barely conscious, emaciated, sun-dazed. Bobbing, sloshing. Very quiet. We hold on him for a long time. It is difficult to tell i he is even breathing. A shadow cuts his face. Louie fights his eyes open, fights to focus. Phil. We hear Phil’s voice, very weak:
Yeah.

He blinks, looks: His point-of-view: low jooking s steeply up at a Japanese stepping aways the blindfold dan giing from one hand. He through the door and it is closed after him. After a beat:  71
Phil? A voice, distant and small, somewhere to the left:
Louie.
.» . You okay?
Land feels funny.

Funny, yeah. We hear Japanese yelling from down the hall, and a door opening, a couple of footsteps, and a blow. Louie, listening to Phil taking a beating. Louie pounds at the door. He tries to see through the cra but can’t.
Louie sits on floor, forearms on knees, hands dangle limp head sunk below shoulders.
A small beam of morning sunlight illuminates the cell wal Louie lifts his face into it as if trying to escape into light. He then notices something - Scratched into the plank wall, a message:

We hear the chink of silver on china. Louie stands in the pouring rain, looking fixedly off: A table set with linen and heavy with food, being eaten b JAPANESE OFFICER who sits bone dry under a tarp. TRANSLATOR stands by. The Officer slowly, meticulously, ostentatiously, cuts hi food and eats. He never looks up. Louie looks around to get his bearings. He is surrounded trees. At closer look, Japanese Soldiers in green uniform stare out from the jungle. No chance for escape. The Officer says something to his plate.
Colonel would like to know disposition of troop in Hawaii. Louie is blank for a moment.
I, I don’t know.

- + +. I wouldn’t know what it is now, haven’t been there in... Murmuring in Japanese. Is this you? Louie nods. The Officer studies him. He says something to Translator in Japanese. The only word Louie can understan “Olympic.” The men share a look. Then the Translator asks another question. TRANSLATOR (CONT’D) You were a famous Olympic athlete? Something else is said.

We had the old one. D-class.
You bomba deer?

How you work the Nawdn bombsight?

Draw Nawdn bombsight. Louie hesitates for a moment, then moves into the tent. H shakes off his wet hand before he tries to start drawing. It’s hard to draw with the drops of water covering the pa The translator has his head cocked, looking down over Lou shoulder.  139 140 141 75 Scratch of pencil on paper. Offhand, as Louie draws:
They were beheaded. Louie takes this in. He continues to draw.
Louie is being led back to his cell. As he passes Phil, also under guard: His tracking, panning point-of-view of Phil, looking up-quickly lost from sight.
.» . . I drew a Philco radio, knobs on the side. The guard shoves him from behind.

Close on Louie’s hand finishing a message by scratching t wall with his belt buckle: LOUIE ZAMPERINI - DITCHED OVER PACIFIC - May 1943 Message finished he sits back against the opposite wall. looks across the three-foot throw of the room: The nine Marines. His name underneath. He stares at the wall, wondering if he will share their s ate. He sees a spider crawl across the wall.

Three weeks have passed. Louie has been in the cell for a month. We find him in tucked into the corner. His beard h grown longer and his face has gone pale. But he seems stronger. He seems focused. He presses his face against the cold cell wall. As if try to connect to Phil.  142 143 144 76 Shouting close by: Louie braces himself as the door is fl open and a guard screams at him, the same word, over and over. Louie, uncomprehending. The guard keeps repeating, shouting, now showing by gestu that Louie is to stand. Louie knows he is being asked to to his death. He refuses. He fights. INT. LOUIE’S CELL/ CELL BLOCK - KWAJALIEN - DAY 142 The door opens and TWO GUARDS aggressively attempt to dra him out. Louie fighting the whole way. Finally, they overpower him and force him out. The light is almost blinding after days of confinement.

Louie sees Phil, also being dragged, in equally bad shape They are scared as they are led out of the cell block. Louie still fighting, Phil seems to be quietly praying as preparing to die. Louie and Phil are being told to stand at attention. The Guards step away.

Strip! TAKE OFF CLOTHES! Louie and Phil strip down before Guards holding rifles. T two terrified men fully expect to be executed. Louie eyes swords on the mens belts. They are told to kneel. Louie and Phil’s hearts pump fast Louie hesitates and is taken down by a smack to the back his knees by a wooden stick. After a terrifying moment of silence, suddenly, Louie and Phil are doused with cold water, shocking their systems. Soap is placed in front of the men and shaving equipment scissors. They begin to wash their frail bodies. INT. SHIP’S PRISON - DAY 144 Close on Phil. Wide to reveal this is Louie’s POV from un his blindfold. Louie and Phil, lay together on the cold f of a storage room. Cleaned up "put still in the same dirt clothes. After days in solitary confinement, they lay ver close to each other.
